Ransom hackers hit Georgia courts after cities pay $1M


By Daniel Uria



















 
July 8 (UPI) -- Hackers behind what appear to be a series of specialized and repeating ransomware attacks against a number of U.S. cities -- holding hostage key computer systems for hundreds of thousands of dollars -- are keeping up the assault after at least two cities paid them off.
source: Ransom hackers hit Georgia courts after cities pay $1M - UPI.com.html

text: The hackers began to attract attention with a cyberattack in early May against multiple systems in Baltimore and Greenville, N.C.
source: Ransom hackers hit Georgia courts after cities pay $1M - UPI.com.html

text: In Baltimore, which paid the hackers nothing, some of those systems are still down.
source: Ransom hackers hit Georgia courts after cities pay $1M - UPI.com.html

text: Two cities in Florida, however, have paid the hackers a combined amount that surpasses $1 million.
source: Ransom hackers hit Georgia courts after cities pay $1M - UPI.com.html

text: Both cities, Riviera Beach and Lake City, said they did so to quickly get back control of the hijacked files -- but experts fear paying the criminals is precisely what may be encouraging new attacks.
source: Ransom hackers hit Georgia courts after cities pay $1M - UPI.com.html

text:
Advertisement
Georgia's state court system and Eurofins Scientific, one of Britain's largest forensics lab, have also been targeted.
source: Ransom hackers hit Georgia courts after cities pay $1M - UPI.com.html

text: BBC News reported Eurofins paid the ransom, but the amount wasn't disclosed.
source: Ransom hackers hit Georgia courts after cities pay $1M - UPI.com.html

text:
Advertisement
Bruce Shaw, a spokesman for the Georgia court system, told UPI at least a portion of the digital information systems in Atlanta were taken offline.
source: Ransom hackers hit Georgia courts after cities pay $1M - UPI.com.html

text: The attackers left a note requesting contact but did not include further demands or a specific ransom, he said.
source: Ransom hackers hit Georgia courts after cities pay $1M - UPI.com.html

text:
Related

Shaw added there's no evidence yet of data mining and the affected servers did not contain any personal information.
source: Ransom hackers hit Georgia courts after cities pay $1M - UPI.com.html

text: Atlanta has previously been targeted by a ransomware attack -- in 2018, when the intrusion cost the city $18 million in recovery efforts.
source: Ransom hackers hit Georgia courts after cities pay $1M - UPI.com.html

text: The court system joins the two Florida cities, plus Key Biscayne, on the growing victims list.
source: Ransom hackers hit Georgia courts after cities pay $1M - UPI.com.html

text: Riviera Beach's city council voted unanimously to pay at least $600,000 ransom through an insurance plan to recover files, and have committed to spend $1 million on new computer security.
source: Ransom hackers hit Georgia courts after cities pay $1M - UPI.com.html

text: Lake City paid $460,000 from city insurance and $10,000 in public money -- and fired its information technology chief.
source: Ransom hackers hit Georgia courts after cities pay $1M - UPI.com.html

text: Key Biscayne has not paid the ransom.
source: Ransom hackers hit Georgia courts after cities pay $1M - UPI.com.html

text: The target cities have since been able to revive a portion of their systems or files, but experts say they face ongoing vulnerabilities from the intrusions.
source: Ransom hackers hit Georgia courts after cities pay $1M - UPI.com.html

text: Authorities are not yet sure if all, or any, of the ransomware attacks are connected.
source: Ransom hackers hit Georgia courts after cities pay $1M - UPI.com.html

text:
Advertisement
Lake City Police Sgt.
source: Ransom hackers hit Georgia courts after cities pay $1M - UPI.com.html

text: Mike Lee said the process has been "slow going.
source: Ransom hackers hit Georgia courts after cities pay $1M - UPI.com.html

text:
"
"We have to take and backup the entire system and then we're recovering from the backups," he said, adding the city uses the process to "start over" if files are corrupted during the recovery process.
source: Ransom hackers hit Georgia courts after cities pay $1M - UPI.com.html

text: Lee said Lake City is performing a forensic analysis to determine whether hackers accessed city systems through phishing, or some other method.
source: Ransom hackers hit Georgia courts after cities pay $1M - UPI.com.html

text: The recent spate of attacks has prompted other cities nationwide to assess their security.
source: Ransom hackers hit Georgia courts after cities pay $1M - UPI.com.html

text: Experts, including law enforcement authorities, have advised cities against paying any ransom amounts.
source: Ransom hackers hit Georgia courts after cities pay $1M - UPI.com.html

text: "They just want to get their money and they're going to leave," Zohar Pinhasi, CEO of cybersecurity firm MonsterCloud, told UPI last month.
source: Ransom hackers hit Georgia courts after cities pay $1M - UPI.com.html

text: "They don't really care about anything else.
source: Ransom hackers hit Georgia courts after cities pay $1M - UPI.com.html

Big Game Hunting with Ryuk: Another Lucrative Targeted Ransomware

January 10, 2019 Alexander Hanel Counter Adversary Operations 


WIZARD SPIDER is a sophisticated eCrime group that has been operating the Ryuk ransomware since August 2018, targeting large organizations for a high-ransom return.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: This methodology, known as “big game hunting,” signals a shift in operations for WIZARD SPIDER.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: This actor is a Russia-based criminal group known for the operation of the TrickBot banking malware that had focused primarily on wire fraud in the past.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The actor name GRIM SPIDER was introduced into CrowdStrike’s nomenclature in September 2018 for the group that operates the Ryuk ransomware as a distinct sub-group of the WIZARD SPIDER criminal enterprise.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: However, in June 2019, further evidence emerged that allowed CrowdStrike to assess with high confidence that Ryuk is in fact operated as part of the core WIZARD SPIDER actor group.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: CrowdStrike Intelligence will now solely use the actor name WIZARD SPIDER in association with TrickBot and Ryuk.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The GRIM SPIDER actor name has been deprecated.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Similar to Samas and BitPaymer, Ryuk is specifically used to target enterprise environments.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Code comparison between versions of Ryuk and Hermes ransomware indicates that Ryuk was derived from the Hermes source code and has been under steady development since its release.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Hermes is commodity ransomware that has been observed for sale on forums and used by multiple threat actors.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: However, Ryuk is only used by WIZARD SPIDER and, unlike Hermes, Ryuk has only been used to target enterprise environments.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Since Ryuk’s appearance in August, the threat actors operating it have netted over 705.80 BTC across 52 transactions for a total current value of $3,701,893.98 USD.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text:
Want the latest insights on the cyber threat landscape?Download the 2021 Global Threat Report

1.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text:
Ryuk Ransom Notes
The Ryuk ransom note is written to a file named RyukReadMe.txt.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: A number of different ransom note templates have been observed.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The body of the template is static with the exception of the email address and the Bitcoin (BTC) wallet address, which may change.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The email addresses usually contain one address at protonmail.com and another address at tutanota.com.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The email names typically are esoteric actors and directors, but Instagram models have also been observed.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Interestingly, the ransom note in Figure 3 is remarkably similar to the BitPaymer ransom notes.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: As of this writing, it remains unclear if WIZARD SPIDER is copying the TTPs (tactics, techniques and procedures) and ransom notes of BitPaymer, or whether the groups may share information with each other.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Figure 3.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Ryuk Ransom Note Bearing Strong Resemblance to BitPaymer
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The ransom email used by Ryuk appears to be unique for each compiled executable.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Our Using threat intelligence, our team has observed several different email addresses, but the same BTC addresses across multiple Ryuk executables.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: On Nov. 29, 2018, WIZARD SPIDER changed how they communicated with their victims.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: As seen in the previous ransom note version, WIZARD SPIDER included their BTC address and email addresses.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: However, recent variants of Ryuk no longer contain the BTC address — only the email addresses.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The ransom note states that the victim will receive the BTC address as a reply from WIZARD SPIDER.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The new ransom note can be seen below.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Figure 4.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text:
Ryuk Ransom With BTC Address Removed
Early Ryuk binaries with the removal of the BTC address contained a PDB path of C:\Users\Admin\Documents\Visual Studio 2015\Projects\ConsoleApplication54new crypted try to clean\x64\Release\ConsoleApplication54.pdb.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: This PDB path started appearing on Nov. 29, 2018.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The removal of the BTC addresses occurred a day after the U.S. Department of Justice unsealed indictments for two individuals involved in facilitating cashouts from Samas Bitcoin addresses.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text:
Ransom Payments
Based on observed transactions to known Ryuk BTC addresses, the ransom demand varies significantly.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: This suggests that WIZARD SPIDER (like INDRIK SPIDER with BitPaymer) calculates the ransom amount based on the size and value of the victim organization.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: To date, the lowest observed ransom was for 1.7 BTC and the highest was for 99 BTC.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: With 52 known transactions spread across 37 BTC addresses (as of this writing), WIZARD SPIDER has made 705.80 BTC, which has a current value of $3.7 million (USD).
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: With the recent decline in BTC to USD value, it is likely GRIM SPIDER has netted more.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The tables in the Appendix include a set of known Ryuk BTC addresses extracted from Ryuk binaries, which are believed to be only a subset of the Ryuk BTC addresses.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html
What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text:
How Ryuk Ransomware is Distributed
CrowdStrike® has conducted multiple incident response (IR) engagements responding to Ryuk infections in which TrickBot was also identified on hosts in the victim environment.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: CrowdStrike Falcon® Intelligence™® believes that the initial compromise is performed through TrickBot, which is typically distributed either via spam email or, through the use of the Emotet (developed and operated by MUMMY SPIDER) geo-based download function.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Falcon Intelligence has been monitoring the geo-based download activity from Emotet and, during 2018, MUMMY SPIDER has been an avid supporter of WIZARD SPIDER, predominantly distributing TrickBot to Emotet victims in the U.K., the U.S., and Canada.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Some of TrickBot’s modules (such as pwgrab) could aid in recovering the credentials needed to compromise environments — the SOCKS module in particular has been observed tunneling PowerShell Empire traffic to perform reconnaissance and lateral movement.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text:
Through CrowdStrike IR engagements, WIZARD SPIDER has been observed performing the following events on the victim’s network, with the end goal of pushing out the Ryuk binary:

An obfuscated PowerShell script is executed and connects to a remote IP address.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: A reverse shell is downloaded and executed on the compromised host.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: PowerShell anti-logging scripts are executed on the host.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Reconnaissance of the network is conducted using standard Windows command line tools along with external uploaded tools.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Lateral movement throughout the network is enabled using Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP).
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Service User Accounts are created.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: PowerShell Empire is downloaded and installed as a service.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Lateral movement is continued until privileges are recovered to obtain access to a domain controller.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: PSEXEC is used to push out the Ryuk binary to individual hosts.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Batch scripts are executed to terminate processes/services and remove backups, followed by the Ryuk binary.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html
What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text:
From Hermes to Ryuk: Similarities & Differences
Hermes ransomware, the predecessor to Ryuk, was first distributed in February 2017.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Only one month after its release, a decryptor was written for Hermes, followed by the release of version 2.0 in April 2017, which fixed vulnerabilities in its cryptographic implementation.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Since this release, the only way for a victim to recover files is with the private encryption key, which is obtained by paying the ransom.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: In late August 2017, Hermes version 2.1 was released.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Hermes was originally sold on forums for $300 USD.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: When purchased, the buyer received a build that supported two email addresses, a decryptor and a unique RSA key pair.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: If the purchaser desired more email addresses, they were required to purchase another build for an additional $50.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The seller of Hermes ransomware appears to have stopped or limited advertising on forums in 2017.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Early versions of Hermes were reportedly installed via internet-accessible RDP servers protected by weak credentials.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: In October 2017, Hermes was deployed as a destructive distraction for a Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication (SWIFT) compromise at the Far Eastern International Bank (FEIB) in Taiwan.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Hermes’ role in the SWIFT attack is described in more detail in the Attribution section at the end of this blog.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: In March 2018, Hermes was observed targeting users in South Korea via the GreenFlash Sundown exploit kit.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: In mid-August 2018, a modified version of Hermes, dubbed Ryuk, started appearing in a public malware repository.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Ryuk was tailored to target enterprise environments and some of the modifications include removing anti-analysis checks.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: These checks include querying the Process Environment Block (PEB) to see if the field is BeingDebugged, or querying the PEB to see if the field NtGlobalFlag has been set; checking to see if the host is running VirtualBox by calling the instruction CPUID; and ensuring that the host language is not Russian, Ukrainian, or Belarusian.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: From a process and file perspective, Hermes and Ryuk target files in a similar fashion.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The core differences are Ryuk’s logic that handles file access, and the use of a second, embedded public RSA key.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text:
The following are characteristics that have not changed:

Encrypts files using RSA-2048 and AES-256
Stores keys in the executable using the proprietary Microsoft SIMPLEBLOB format
Encrypts mounted devices and remote hosts
Uses a file marker of HERMES to mark or check if a file has been encrypted

Another notable difference between Hermes and Ryuk is how the encryption keys are created.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Hermes starts the encryption initialization by first generating an RSA public and private key pair  — referred to as a “victim key.”
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: An AES-256 key is generated and the victim’s RSA private key is encrypted in AES-CBC mode.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The attacker-controlled public RSA key is used to encrypt the AES key (previously used to encrypt the victim’s RSA private key).
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Then, for each file encrypted, an AES key is generated, which is used to encrypt the file.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Finally, the AES key for each file is encrypted with the victim’s RSA public key, then stored at the end of the file.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Ryuk contains the same logic, but no longer generates the victim-specific RSA key pair.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Instead, Ryuk has two public RSA keys embedded in the executable, and what was previously the victim’s RSA private key is encrypted and embedded in the executable.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Because Ryuk does not generate a victim-specific RSA key pair, all hosts can be decrypted with the same decryption key.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: This might appear to be a design flaw but is not, since Ryuk has a unique key for each executable.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: If a single executable is used for a single victim environment, then there are no repercussions if the private keys are leaked because it will only decrypt the damage from a single Ryuk executable.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Thus, it is highly likely that Ryuk pre-generates the RSA key pairs for each victim.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: This is arguably more secure, since the victim’s system will never have access to the unencrypted RSA key pair parameters without paying the ransom.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: This approach is similar to INDRIK SPIDER’s BitPaymer ransomware, which generates a victim-specific sample with a hard-coded public key.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text:
4. Ryuk Functionality: A Technical Analysis
There are two types of Ryuk binaries: a dropper (which is not commonly observed) and the Ryuk executable payload.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Recovery of Ryuk droppers are rare, due to the Ryuk executable payload deleting the dropper when executed.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Upon execution, the dropper constructs an installation folder path.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The folder path is created by calling GetWindowsDirectoryW and then inserting a null byte at the fourth character of the path.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: This is used to create a string that contains the drive letter path.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: If the host operating system is Windows XP or earlier, the string Documents and Settings\Default User\ is appended to the drive letter path.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: If the host is Windows Vista or newer, the string users\Public\ is appended to the drive letter path.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: For Windows XP, an example folder path would be C:\Documents and Settings\Default User\, and for Window Vista or higher, the path would be C:\Users\Public.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: A random executable file name is then constructed.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: It is created by calling _srand with a seed value returned from calling GetTickCount, then _rand is continuously called until five alphabetic characters are concatenated together.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The extension .exe is then appended.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The dropper checks whether the host is 32-bit or 64-bit by calling IsWow64Process and writes one of two embedded payload executables corresponding to the host’s architecture.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The newly written executable is then run by calling ShellExecuteW.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The Ryuk payload executable written by the dropper is the Ryuk component that contains the core logic for encrypting files on the host.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Ryuk is under constant development.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: In recent months, Ryuk binaries have continued to deviate further and further from the original Hermes source code, with the threat actors adding and removing functionality often.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: In November 2018, Falcon Intelligence identified new functionality added to Ryuk that included an anti-analysis infinite loop, a ping-like request to an IP address once the encryption process was completed, and the addition of an appended file extension for encrypted files.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Of these three new features, only the file extension is still present in an executable compiled on Dec. 20, 2018.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text:
File Encryption
Compared to other families of ransomware
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: , Ryuk has very few safeguards to ensure stability of the host by not encrypting system files.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: For example, many ransomware families contain extensive lists of file extensions or folder names that should not be encrypted (whitelisted), but Ryuk only whitelists three extensions: It will not encrypt files with the extensions exe, dll, or hrmlog.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The last extension appears to be a debug log filename created by the original Hermes developer.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: It should be noted that absent from this list is sys (system drivers), ocx (OLE control extension) and other executable file types.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Encrypting these files could make the host unstable.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Early versions of Ryuk included the whitelisting of ini and lnk files, but these have been removed in recent builds.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The following folder names are also whitelisted and not encrypted.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text:
Chrome
Mozilla
Recycle.bin
Windows
Microsoft
AhnLab

This is only a small subset of folder names that should be whitelisted in order to ensure stability on the host.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: While doing dynamic analysis, it was not uncommon to observe Ryuk attempting to encrypt files related to the Windows Bootloader (C:\Boot) or other critical files and folders.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Due to the absence of proper whitelisting, an infected machine can become unstable over time and unbootable if restarted.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: As mentioned in the Hermes to Ryuk section, Ryuk uses a combination of symmetric (AES) and asymmetric (RSA) encryption to encrypt files.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Without the private key provided by WIZARD SPIDER, the files cannot be decrypted and are unrecoverable.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: A thread is created for the encryption of each file and each file is encrypted with its own AES key.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: After the file has been encrypted, a file extension of .RYK is appended to the file.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: All directories will have a ransom note of (RyukReadMe.txt) written to the directory.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Ryuk attempts to encrypt all mounted drives and hosts that have Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) entries (IP addresses) and it enumerates all mounted drives by calling GetLogicalDrives.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: For each mounted drive, Ryuk calls GetDriveTypeW to determine the drive’s type.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: If the drive type is not a CD-ROM, files on the drive are encrypted.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: To retrieve IP addresses that have ARP entries, Ryuk calls GetIpNetTable.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: It iterates through all entries and then tries to enumerate files and folders on the remote host and encrypt the files.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text:
Persistence
Current builds of Ryuk no longer contain persistence functionality.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Previously, to remain persistent on the host, Ryuk created a registry entry under the Run key using Windows cmd.exe shell.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The following command line was used to write to the Registry Run Key name svchos to  HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run with the value being the path to the Ryuk executable.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text:
Process Injection
Ryuk does not encrypt files from within its own process memory space, but injects into a remote process.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Before injecting into a remote process, Ryuk attempts to adjust its token privileges to have the SeDebugPrivilege.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: It takes no action if the adjustment of the token privileges fails.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Before injecting into a remote process, Ryuk also calls CreateToolhelp32Snapshot to enumerate all running processes.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: If a process is found that is not named csrss.exe, explorer.exe, lsaas.exe, or is running under NT AUTHORITY system account, Ryuk will inject itself into this single process.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: By ensuring that the process is not running under NT AUTHORITY, the developers are assuming the process is not running under another account and therefore can be written to.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Ryuk uses a combination of VirtualAlloc, WriteProcessMemory and CreateRemoteThread to inject itself into the remote process.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text:
Process/Service Termination and Anti-Recovery Commands
Unlike other families of ransomware, Ryuk does not contain process/service termination and anti-recovery functionality embedded in the executable.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: In the past, Ryuk did contain these capabilities, but they have been removed and are contained within two batch files.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The batch file kill.bat contains commands for stopping services, disabling services and killing processes.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The processes and services are stopped to ensure no open handles exist for files that will be encrypted.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The following figure is a subset of each command.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text:
net stop avpsus /y
net stop McAfeeDLPAgentService /y
net stop mfewc /y
net stop BMR Boot Service /y
net stop NetBackup BMR MTFTP Service /y
…
sc config SQLTELEMETRY start= disabled
sc config SQLTELEMETRY$ECWDB2 start= disabled
sc config SQLWriter start= disabled
sc config SstpSvc start= disabled
…
taskkill /IM mspub.exe /F
taskkill /IM mydesktopqos.exe /F
taskkill /IM mydesktopservice.exe /F
Figure 1.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text:

CrowdStrike has observed another batch file, named windows.bat, which makes file recovery more difficult on the victim’s machine.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text:
Anti-Recovery window.bat Commands
These anti-forensic recovery commands are quite interesting and appear to make use of an undocumented feature of the vssadmin resize command.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: While the first command in Figure 2 above, vssadmin Delete Shadows /all /quiet, is commonly used by ransomware, the command option vssadmin resize shadowstorage is rarely used.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: In situations where shadow copies were not created by vssadmin, but by third-party applications (such as backup software), vssadmin can display an error and not delete the backups.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: One such error states: “Snapshots were found, but they were outside of your allowed context.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Try removing them with the backup application which created them.”
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The vssadmin resize shadowstorage command is a “hack” that relies on vssadmin to delete storage when the shadow copies are resized.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: It forces the shadow copies to be deleted regardless of their context.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The command works by resizing the default shadow volume size from 10 percent to 401 MB (the minimum size is 300 MB).
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Then the shadow storage is set to unbounded, which allows it to use all available disk space.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The shadow copies are then deleted by calling the command vssadmin Delete Shadows /all
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: /quiet a second time.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The final set of commands deletes files based on their extension or folder locations.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The command arguments are for del delete files in all sub-directories (/s) in quiet mode (/q) without asking the user for confirmation and to force (/f)  the deletion of a file.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The file extensions are for Virtual Hard Disk (.VHD), Avantrix Backup Plus files (.bac), backup copy (.bak), Windows Backup Catalog File (.wbcat), Windows Backup Utility File (.bfk), setting files (.set), Windows Backup File (.win), Disk Images (.dsk) and all folders that start with Backup.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Note that since the del command does not securely delete a file (i.e., overwrite a file before deletion), some level of file recovery may be possible using forensic tools.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The last command of del %0 deletes the executing .bat
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: file.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The anti-recovery commands used by Ryuk are more extensive than most ransomware families.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: These commands have not been observed being used by other ransomware families yet.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: This indicates that the threat actors have a thorough understanding of enterprise backup software.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text:
5. Attribution
North Korea
Open-source reporting has claimed that the Hermes ransomware was developed by the North Korean group STARDUST CHOLLIMA (activities of which have been public reported as part of the “Lazarus Group”), because Hermes was executed on a host during the SWIFT compromise of FEIB in October 2017.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Table 1 contains samples that are possibly attributed to the compromise.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The two executables related to Hermes are bitsran.exe and RSW7B37.tmp.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text:
File Information for Binaries Used in the FEIB SWIFT Compromise
The first executable, bitsran.exe, is a dropper, and RSW7B37.tmp is the Hermes ransomware executable.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The dropper’s goal is to propagate the Hermes executable within a network by creating scheduled tasks over SMB sessions using hard-coded credentials.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The Hermes executable then encrypts files on the host.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: It is interesting to note that the compiler and linker for Hermes is different from the other executables.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: All of the executables except for Hermes were compiled with Visual Studio 10, with a linker of Visual Studio 10.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Hermes, in contrast, was compiled with Visual Studio 9, with an unknown linker.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: If the time stamps are correct, the two executables (bitsran.exe and RSW7B37.tmp) were compiled within four hours and three minutes of each other.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Due to the short time frame of Hermes being bundled within an executable that was hard-coded with credentials of the FEIB network, Falcon Intelligence assesses that STARDUST CHOLLIMA likely had access to the Hermes source code, or a third party compiled and built a new version for them.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Unlike other variants of Hermes, RSW7B37.tmp does not append the exported and encrypted AES key to the end of the file.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Figure 5 is a file encrypted by Hermes with the exported AES key appended to the end of the file as a footer.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Figure 5.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text:
Example Hermes Footer with Encrypted AES Key
Figure 6 is the end of a file encrypted by the Hermes variant RSW7B37.tmp used in the SWIFT attack.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The footer only contains the marker HERMES but not the exported AES key.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Figure 6.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text:
Example Hermes Footer in FEIB SWIFT Attack with Encrypted AES Key Missing
Without the encrypted AES key appended to the encrypted files, even if the private key used for encryption was recovered, the files could not be decrypted.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Therefore, the Hermes executable used in the FEIB SWIFT attack appears never to have been used to ransom the machine, but rather to destroy the victim’s data.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text:
Criminal Actors Operating from Russia
Falcon Intelligence has medium-high confidence that the WIZARD SPIDER threat actors are operating out of Russia.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Hermes was originally advertised on exploit[.]in.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: This Russian-speaking forum is a well-known marketplace for selling malware and related services to criminal threat actors.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: If Hermes was indeed related to STARDUST CHOLLIMA, it would imply that nation-state threat actors are selling their services on Russian-speaking forums, which is unlikely.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The Russian threat actor attribution theory is also supported by an early advertisement for Hermes, which stated that their “software did not work and will on work on RU, UA, BY” [sic].
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: This refers to functionality implemented in Hermes to check the host to ensure that it is not running on a Russian, Ukrainian, or Belarusian system.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: To check the host language, it queries the registry key HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Nls\Language\ and the value InstallLanguage.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: If the machine has the value 0419 (Russian), 0422 (Ukrainian) or 0423 (Belarusian), it call ExitProcess to stop executing.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: This functionality is commonly included by malware developers and sellers who are operating in Russia to reduce their risk of attracting local law enforcement’s attention and criminal prosecution.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: While supporting an incident response investigation involving Ryuk, Falcon Intelligence noticed files related to the investigation being uploaded to a file-scanning website from an IP address in Moscow, Russia.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The file in question was a variant of kill.bat that contained commands previously only observed executed by Ryuk calling ShellExecute.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The files could have been uploaded by a victim in Russia, but the time frame between the functionality being removed from Ryuk binaries and included in kill.bat was very short.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: The most likely scenario is that threat actors were testing whether kill.bat would be detected by antivirus engines.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Also, during forensic investigation of a network compromised by WIZARD SPIDER, CrowdStrike Services recovered artifacts with filenames in Russian.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: One file was named !!!
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: files dlya raboty !!!
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: .rar, which translates to “files for work.”
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: Based on these factors, there is considerably more evidence supporting the hypothesis that the WIZARD SPIDER threat actors are Russian speakers and not North Korean.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text:
How CrowdStrike Can Prevent Ryuk
The Falcon platform has the ability to detect and prevent Ryuk by taking advantage of the behavioral patterns indicated by the ransomware.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: By turning on suspicious process blocking, Falcon ensures that Ryuk is killed in the very early stages of execution.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text: In addition, CrowdStrike’s machine learning (ML) algorithm provides additional coverage against this malware family, as illustrated below.
source: What is Ryuk Ransomware_ The Complete Breakdown.html

text:
Published Oct. 29, 2020
    






                        
                        
                            Samantha Schwartz
                        
                        
                        
                            Reporter


















































Stock Photo via Getty Images







Ryuk ransomware fell off the radar when the coronavirus began its global spread.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: Its silence hinted at its expiration or a rebrand in the form of the Conti ransomware.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: Really, Ryuk was just in hibernation between April and August.

text: Obviously, we were really, really wrong,” said Aaron Stephens, senior threat analyst on Mandiant’s FLARE Advanced Practices Team, while speaking during a SANS Institute webcast Wednesday.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: Mandiant found that threat group UNC1878 is responsible for one-fifth of Ryuk intrusions.

text: “Herein lies our monster,” said Stephens during the webcast.

text: The cybersecurity firm released research on UNC1878’s indicators Wednesday following news of attacks on hospitals.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: Mandiant researchers coined “UNC,” shorthand for uncategorized, as part of their research processes, they needed “UNCs” to help organize unique malicious activity.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: “At a fundamental level UNCs serve as labels for which you can bucket indicators and techniques into.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: This labeled bucket would then act as technical anchor for what we are seeing is related activity,” said Van Ta, senior threat analyst on Mandiant’s FLARE Advanced Practices Team, speaking on the webcast.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: “Instead of labeling an evidence bag, ‘the Overlook Hotel’, we’re labeling it UNC1878.”
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: “We began to see Ryuk make its harrowing return.

text: It wasn’t dead.

text:
It was undead.”


Aaron Stephens

Ryuk gameplan
UNC1878 traditionally relied on Trickbot, which provides initial access and visibility, and used Cobalt Strike with everyone of its intrusions.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: UNC1878 obtains credentials using Mimikatz, LaZagne and Kerbrute.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: “With legitimate credentials UNC1878 extended their access by connecting to network shares and directly to systems over RDP and SSH,” said Ta.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: This month, Microsoft was granted permission to disable Trickbot’s critical infrastructure.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: A week into the disruption, Microsoft claimed to have eliminated “94% of Trickbot’s critical operational infrastructure including both the command-and-control servers in use at the time our action began and new infrastructure Trickbot has attempted to bring online.”

Ryuk typically uses Emotet for a phishing or RDP attack, but Sophos studied a September Ryuk attack which showcased a different tactic outside of Emotet and Trickbot.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: “It marked the return of Ryuk with some minor modifications” and next-generation attack tools, according to Sophos’ report.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: “People think ransomware, and the malware cocktails, they’re just re-flavoring.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: But if you look at Ryuk, they’re using it as a malware cocktail, not just changing the ingredients,” said Bill Conner, CEO of SonicWall.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text:
In the September attack Sophos investigated, the malicious document in the phishing email executed Buer Loader, a modular malware as a service downloader, to get access. 
Time to Ryuk 
The September Ryuk incident Sophos investigated uncovered a quick infection-to-deployment time after someone opened the phishing email.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: It took 3 1/2 hours.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: While each installment attempt failed, Ryuk’s operators persevered, “including renewed phishing attempts to re-establish a foothold,” according to Sophos.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: Operators behind Ryuk are “really recreating these malware cocktails and bundles, if you will, to make them much more lethal,” which increases their speed and scalability, said Conner.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: UNC1878’s “time to Ryuk,” or intrusion to execution time, was on average about five days and 17 hours.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: It is demonstrably faster than other ransomware’s “dwell time,” roughly 72 days and 12 hours, according to data from 2019.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: UNC1878 could “ransom 13 environments in the same amount of time,” said Stephens.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: When UNC1878 is ready to deploy Ryuk, it will drop the zip file into the PerfLogs directory.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: “They’ll then unzip into a directory they create named “share$,” said Ta.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: Coupled with text files are the ransomware binary and patch files for malware propagation.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: There are three ”.bat” scripts used for iterating computer names to execute Ryuk.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: At the beginning of the year, UNC1878 used Trickbot, Cobalt Strike and Ryuk.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: But Ryuk’s return doesn’t necessarily mean UNC1878 returned too.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

“This new wave of Ryuk intrusions have essentially replaced Trickbot with Kegtap, a similar but distinctly different malware family,” said Stephens.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: Kegtap is among campaigns sent to targets with ever-changing ”delivery tactics, techniques and procedures,” according to Mandiant.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: Campaigns like Kegtap have shifted from delivery via Sendgrid to having URLs host malware payload “associated with one or more of these legitimate services.”
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: Even the use of Cobalt Strike isn’t the same as it once was, particularly seen in TLS certificates.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: Mandiant noticed differentiation in certificates, nuances in domain patterns, and general overlaps in activity.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: Researchers identified a newly-minted UNC2352 as the successor to UNC1878.
source: Ryuk wakes from hibernation; FBI, DHS warn of healthcare attacks _ Cybersecurity Dive.html

text: “If these two groups should really be the same, the data will tell us and in this case, it did,” said Stephens.

Malware
Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities
Trickbot's authors clearly aren't done updating it  — we recently found a new variant that uses an updated version of the pwgrab module that lets it grab remote application credentials.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text:
By: Noel Anthony Llimos, Carl Maverick Pascual
		
			February 12, 2019
Read time: 3 min (681 words)
	















Save to Folio






 Subscribe
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: In November 2018, we covered a Trickbot variant that came with a password-grabbing module, which allowed it to steal credentials from numerous applications.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: In January 2019, we saw Trickbot (detected as TrojanSpy.Win32.TRICKBOT.AZ and Trojan.Win32.MERETAM.AD) with new capabilities added to its already extensive bag of tricks.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: Its authors clearly aren't done updating Trickbot — we recently found a new variant that uses an updated version of the pwgrab module that lets it grab remote application credentials.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text:
Infection Chain
Figure 1.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text:
Infection chain for the malware
Technical Analysis
The malware arrives via an email disguised as a tax incentive notification from a major financial services company.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: This email includes a macro enabled (XLSM)
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: Microsoft Excel spreadsheet attachment (detected as Trojan.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: W97M.MERETAM.A) that purportedly contains the details of the tax incentive.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: However, as these attachments usually go, this macro is malicious and will download and deploy Trickbot on the user’s machine once activated.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: Figure 2.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: The spam email containing the malicious macro-enabled attachment.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: Figure 3.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text:
Screenshot of the attached spreadsheet document
This Trickbot variant is largely similar to the variant we discovered in November.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: However, the 2019 version adds three new functions, one each for the Virtual Network Computing (VNC), PuTTY, and Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) platforms.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: Figure 4.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: Comparison of the pwgrab modules from November 2018 (top) and January 2019 (bottom).
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: Note the added functions in the code.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: Figure 5.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: C&C traffic with the RDP credentials being sent.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: One of the techniques enforced by these new functions encrypts the strings it uses via simple variants of XOR or SUB routines.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: Figure 6.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: XOR routine (top) and SUB routine (bottom) string encryption.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: It also makes use of API hashes for indirect API calling, which was prominently attributed to the Carberp trojan source code leak from 2013.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: Figure 7.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: API hashing artifact from the Carberp Source Code.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text:
VNC
To grab VNC credentials, the pwgrab module searches for files using the “*.vnc.lnk” affix that are located in the following directories:

%APPDATA%\Microsoft\Windows\Recent 
%USERPROFILE%\Documents, %USERPROFILE%\Downloads
  

The stolen information includes the target machine's hostname, port, and the proxy settings.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: Figure 8.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: Screenshot of how pwgrab locates “.vnc.lnk” files on the %USERPROFILE%\Downloads directory.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: The module will send the required data via POST, which is configured through a downloaded configuration file using the filename “dpost.”
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text:
This file contains a list of command-and-control (C&C) servers that will receive the exfiltrated data from the victim.

Figure 9.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: Stolen Information being exfiltrated to the C&C server.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text:
PuTTY
To retrieve the PuTTY credentials, it queries the registry key Software\SimonTatham\Putty\Sessions to identify the saved connection settings, which allows the module to retrieve information such as the Hostname and Username, and Private Key Files used for authentication.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: Figure 10.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: Registry traversal for Putty data exfiltration (left), code showing hostname, username and Private Key Files (right).
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: RDP
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: Its third function related to RDP uses the CredEnumerateA API to identify and steal saved credentials.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: It then parses the string “target=TERMSRV” to identify the hostname, username, and password saved per RDP credential.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text:
Recommendations
These new additions to the already “tricky” Trickbot show one strategy that many authors use to improve the capabilities of their creations: gradual evolution of existing malware.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: While this new variant is not groundbreaking in terms of what it can do, it proves that the groups or individuals behind Trickbot are not resting on their laurels and continuously improve it, making an already-dangerous malware even more effective.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: Fortunately, users can nip these attacks in the bud simply by following the best practices against spam.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: This includes being aware of the main characteristics of a spam email, such as a suspicious sender address and multiple grammatical errors.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

text: We also recommended that users refrain from opening email attachments unless they are sure that it is from a legitimate source.
source: Trickbot Adds Credential-Grabbing Capabilities.html

Ransomware-as-a-service: The pandemic within a pandemic
Nov 16, 2020

























Share this article on Facebook



Share this article on Facebook

Share this article on LinkedIn



















Ransomware is a massive problem.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: But you already knew that.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: Technical novices, along with seasoned cybersecurity professionals, have witnessed over the past year a slew of ransomware events that have devastated enterprises around the world.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: Even those outside of cybersecurity are now familiar with the concept: criminals behind a keyboard have found a way into an organization’s system, prevented anyone from actually using it by locking it up, and won’t let anyone resume normal activity until the organization pays a hefty fee.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: As economies around the world teeter on the edge of disaster as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, the onslaught of ransomware attacks in 2020 has compounded civil society’s ability to carry on business as usual.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: Corporations, governments, schools and everything in between have constantly been in the crosshairs of underground criminal groups, often left with very little recourse if they find their systems have been locked.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: That lack of recourse doesn’t mean there’s an absence of effort to beat the bad guys.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: But even for seasoned professionals, it’s a challenge to measure and quantify just how bad ransomware has gotten.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: While incidents continue to come to light, there is a lot the cybersecurity industry doesn’t know: the volume of attacks, average cost of remediation and organizations who choose to stay silent once an attack has occurred.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: What is known is that the criminal groups behind ransomware are flourishing, creating new variants and offering access on underground markets to anyone that has access to corporate networks and a desire to make a substantial amount of illicit money.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: Intel 471 has been tracking over 25 different ransomware-as-a-service crews over the past year, ranging from well-known groups that have become synonymous with ransomware, to newly-formed variants that have risen from the failures of old, to completely new variants that may have the ability to unseat the current top-level cabals.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: The following is an examination of Ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) crews that have grown over the past year.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: This is not meant to be a definitive measure of the ransomware scene, as what could be considered “damaging” — payment amount, system downtime, communications with attackers — could vary by crew or incident.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: Additionally, there are known private gangs operating in tight, close-knit criminal circles using direct and private communication channels that we have little visibility into.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: What we are aiming to do is shine light on an area where relative darkness has led to a staggering amount of criminals running roughshod over enterprises, escaping with people’s hard-earned money while facing very limited consequences.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: By speaking publicly on these operations, society as a whole can get a better understanding of the rising problem at hand.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text:
TIER 3: Emerging RaaS Crews
We can verify that the following variants have been created and are being sold on a RaaS model, but at the present time, there is limited to no information on successful attacks, volume of attacks, payments received or cost of mitigation.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

The following variants have been tied to a number of confirmed attacks, the frequency of which have grown over 2020.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: A number of these variants have utilized blogs to “name and shame” victims who have refused to pay ransoms.

source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text:
MespinozaAugust 2020Over 40N/AYesRagnarDecember 2019Over 25ExploitYesRanzyOctober 20201Exploit & XSSYesSunCryptOctober 2019Over 20MazafakaYesThanosAugust 2020Over 5RaidNoTIER 1: Most Wanted 
These variants are among the most utilized, constantly showing up in enterprises that have been publicly linked to an attack.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: The variants are often iterations of past RaaS operations that were either shut down or broken up by law enforcement.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: All of these variants have utilized blogs to “name and shame” victims who have refused to pay ransoms.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: In all, these variants have pulled in hundreds of millions in ransoms -- a figure that may be low due to the lack of reporting surrounding enterprises payment to crews.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text:
DoppelPaymer 
DoppelPaymer, around since 2019, is associated with the BitPaymer aka FriedEx ransomware.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: CrowdStrike has highlighted some similarities between those variants, speculating that DoppelPaymer might be the work of the former BitPaymer group members.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: The ransomware itself is usually deployed manually after a network is compromised and sensitive data is exfiltrated.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: The DoppelPaymer team operates a Tor-based “Dopple leaks” blog, which is used to publish information about compromised companies and their stolen data.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: The crew is behind such notable attacks as those on Mexican energy giant Pemex and an IT contractor that works with the U.S. federal government.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: The most known and discussed victim of DoppelPaymer ransomware is one against Düsseldorf University Clinic in September 2020.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: The actors actually wanted to target the Düsseldorf University and addressed it in the ransom note, but ended up hitting the hospital.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: When the perpetrators were made aware, they sent a digital key to get the hospital up and running again.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: DoppelPaymer has been used in over 125 ransomware incidents in 2020.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text:
Egregor/Maze
As this report was being published, the crew behind the Maze ransomware service announced it was shutting down its operations.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: There has been speculation that this group’s affiliates will likely be funneled into the services behind Egregor ransomware.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: Egregor follows a familiar pattern in its operations: Compromise corporate networks to steal sensitive data and deploy ransomware, communicate with victims and demand ransoms, then dump sensitive data on a blog when victim organizations refuse to pay the ransom.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: There is evidence that Egregor is also linked to Sekhmet ransomware.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: Intel 471 researchers found Egregor contained the same Base64 encoded data as Sekhmet where the last row contained additional parameters from a compromised system.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: Researchers also found that Egregor ransom notes were strikingly similar to ones used with Sekhmet.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: Egregor was found in incidents at Crytek, Ubisoft and Barnes & Noble.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: Intel 471 found that Maze was used in over 250 ransomware incidents in 2020.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: Egregor was used in more than 200 incidents.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text:
Netwalker 
First detected in September 2019, NetWalker is one of the more prolific affiliate services Intel 471 has tracked.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: The actors behind it have spent 2020 using phishing emails that leverage the impact and fear of the COVID-19 pandemic to lure victims into loading their malware onto systems.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: In May, the operators launched a Tor-based blog to release sensitive data stolen from victim organizations that refused to pay the requested ransom.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: The actors used a fileless infection technique and allegedly could bypass the user account control component of Windows 7 and newer operating systems.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: NetWalker could be operated in two modes: In “network mode,” individual computers or the entire network could be held for ransom and the victim could purchase a decryption tool with a master key or buy the necessary keys to decrypt certain computers.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: In “individual mode”, a ransom was demanded for a single computer at a time.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: The most high-profile target hit by Netwalker is Michigan State University, which refused to pay the ransom.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: Netwalker has been tied to 143 ransomware incidents in 2020.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text:
REvil
One of the most ubiquitous ransomware variants on the market, deployments of REvil first were observed on April 17, 2019, where attackers leveraged a vulnerability in Oracle WebLogic servers tracked as CVE-2019-2725.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: Two months later, advertisements started popping up on the XSS forum.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: REvil has been one of the most active ransomware gangs in recent memory, claiming responsibility for such attacks as those on U.K.-based financial service provider Travelex, U.S.-based entertainment and media law firm Grubman Shire Meiselas & Sacks and 23 local governments in Texas.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: One of the most common ways the group gains access to organizations is through remote desktop protocol (RDP) vulnerabilities, such as the BlueGate vulnerability, which allows remote code execution by an authorized user.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: The representative admittedly preferred to use information stealers to obtain remote access credentials, which are then used to secure an initial foothold in company networks.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: In the case of the Travelex and Grubman Shire Meiselas & Sacks attacks, the representative said networks were compromised by exploiting outdated Citrix and Pulse Secure remote access software, with the actors allegedly gaining access to an entire network in "about three minutes.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text:
"
While the group carries out attacks on its own, it has found the RaaS model brings back more money.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: Affiliates are responsible for gaining access to target networks, downloading valuable files and deploying the actual ransomware, while the REvil gang handles victim negotiations and blackmailing, ransom collection and distribution.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: This model has apparently led to skyrocketing profits: according to the REvil representative, one affiliate's earnings rose from about US$20,000 to US $30,000 per target with another RaaS offering to about US $7 million to $8 million per target in only six months after joining forces with REvil.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: Intel 471 has linked REvil to 230 ransomware attacks in 2020.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text:
Ryuk
The name “Ryuk” could arguably be categorized as synonymous with ransomware, as the variant is one of the most popular, with a strong affiliate program and a large list of victims.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: It is often delivered as the last action in the chain of infections brought on by dueling use of the Trickbot botnet and Emotet malwares.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: (Intel 471 has previously covered that relationship.)
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: Recently, we have also witnessed that Ryuk is delivered through the Bazar loader.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: Affiliates follow a model in their attacks: Hiring actors to launch spam campaigns to deliver the actor's banking malware.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: Then, another set of actors conduct privilege escalation attacks within compromised corporate networks.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: Then, teams of as many of five deploy the ransomware and handle negotiations with victims.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: Ryuk has exploded over the past year, responsible for millions of ransomware incidents around the world.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: Some security researchers estimate that Ryuk has been found in as much as one-third of ransomware attacks launched this year.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: One of the biggest threats from Ryuk this year has been focused on the healthcare sector.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: The attack that drew the most headlines was the attack on Universal Health Services, one of the biggest hospital systems in the United States.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: While the cybersecurity community recognizes the threat all of these groups present, the criminals are only one part of the picture.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html

text: In our next entry, Intel 471 will examine what a business goes through once it has to recover from a ransomware attack.
source: Ransomware-as-a-service_ The pandemic within a pandemic _ Intel471.html
